headline: Damning Report Reveals Police Executive Cover-Up as Government Faces Grilling on Unemployment and Abuse Redress
summary: Parliament was dominated by a ministerial statement on a damning Independent Police Conduct Authority (IPCA) report, which found former senior police executives engaged in an 'utterly disgraceful' cover-up of serious allegations. The Government also faced intense questioning over rising regional unemployment and its handling of redress for survivors of state abuse. Meanwhile, legislation enabling road congestion charging passed its final reading with unanimous support.

topicSummaries.topic: Police Minister Denounces 'Utterly Disgraceful' Conduct by Former Police Executive in IPCA Report
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The report details a cover-up of serious allegations against a senior officer, raising critical questions about police integrity and public trust.
topicSummaries.content: Minister of Police Mark Mitchell delivered a statement on an IPCA report into the handling of complaints against former Deputy Commissioner Jevon McSkimming. The report found a small group within the former police executive, including a former commissioner, engaged in 'significant flaws in decision making' by failing to investigate serious allegations, attempting to influence the IPCA's investigation, and instead prosecuting the female complainant. Mitchell called the behaviour 'utterly disgraceful' and confirmed the Government and Police accept all IPCA recommendations, including the establishment of an Inspector-General of Police. Labour's Ginny Andersen called it a 'complete failure of duty' that damaged public trust, while the Green Party's Tamatha Paul highlighted that senior officers 'colluded to cover up genuine complaints of abuse and misconduct'.

keyExchanges.speaker: TAMATHA PAUL (Green—Wellington Central)
keyExchanges.quote: We want to know which of the IPCA's recommendations the Government will be implementing, and by when.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon MARK MITCHELL (Minister of Police)
keyExchanges.quote: In relation to the Independent Police Conduct Authority of New Zealand (IPCA) recommendations, both the Police and the Government have been clear that we accept all of those recommendations.

topicSummaries.topic: PM Clashes with Opposition Over Rising Unemployment, Telling Jobseekers to 'Go Where the Jobs Are'
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The exchange highlights a stark policy divide on how to address unemployment, particularly in regions facing significant job losses.
topicSummaries.content: A heated exchange occurred between Prime Minister Christopher Luxon and Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins over rising unemployment. Hipkins challenged the Prime Minister on a 78% increase in unemployment in regions like Hawke's Bay and Gisborne under his government. In response, Luxon defended his government's welfare policies, stating they have 'ambition for young people' and that if they have to move for employment, 'so be it'. Luxon criticized the previous Labour government's record, accusing them of consigning people to welfare.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: Does he stand by his statement "If you want a job, you go where the jobs are."; if so, does he believe the thousands of people in regions like Hawke's Bay and Gisborne, where there are 78 percent more unemployed people under his leadership than before it, should simply pack up and leave their communities?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: We have ambition for young people in New Zealand. We're not just going to consign them for the welfare list where they can sit there for 18 years. We want them connected to employment, training, and work, and if they have to move to do that, so be it.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Defends Redress System for Abuse Survivors Amid Criticism
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The government's approach to compensating survivors of state and faith-based abuse is under scrutiny for being 'broken and retraumatising'.
topicSummaries.content: On the National Day of Reflection for survivors of abuse, Green Co-leader Marama Davidson questioned the Prime Minister on the Government's response to the Royal Commission of Inquiry into Abuse in Care. Davidson asked why the Government scrapped a survivor-led proposal for a new redress system, instead funding what she termed the 'broken and retraumatising existing system'. Prime Minister Christopher Luxon defended the decision, arguing the proposed alternative would be 'time-consuming, expensive, and disruptive' and that his government's approach, backed by $770 million in funding, would get action for survivors faster.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Marama Davidson (Co-Leader—Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Did he scrap the design group's proposal, which would have been a pathway for meaningful redress for survivors, instead funding the broken and retraumatising existing system?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Christopher Luxon (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: We considered lots of different approaches to a redress system, but, at the end of the day, we decided it would be time-consuming, expensive, and disruptive, and, frankly, these survivors have waited too long. So I'm proud of the fact that we've put $770 million into Budget 2025 to move this forward.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Recommits to Military-Style Academies Despite Critical Evaluation
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The government is proceeding with a controversial youth justice policy despite an evaluation suggesting therapeutic interventions are more effective.
topicSummaries.content: Minister for Children Karen Chhour confirmed the Government will not reconsider its military-style academy policy for young offenders, despite a final evaluation report on the pilot programme. Green MP Tamatha Paul challenged the Minister, noting the report highlighted that 'therapeutic interventions worked the best'. Chhour defended the policy, stating that two-thirds of participants reduced their offending and that the military component provided structure and routine that was 'absent from the lives they were living'. She stated she was proud to have given the young people 'a better chance in life'.

keyExchanges.speaker: Tamatha Paul (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: Does she agree with the final evaluation report, which highlights that therapeutic interventions worked the best, and, if so, will she accept that the military element of the pilot was not even needed?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Karen Chhour (Minister for Children)
keyExchanges.quote: What I would say is that there is an approach to this that comes from multiple angles. The military part of the programme had a focus on health and physical activities, including drills, which young people responded to well, and they actually asked for more of those physical activities.

topicSummaries.topic: Time of Use Congestion Charging Bill Passes Final Reading Unanimously
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The new law gives local councils the power to introduce road pricing schemes to manage traffic, with Auckland expected to be the first.
topicSummaries.content: The Land Transport Management (Time of Use Charging) Amendment Bill passed its third and final reading with unanimous support from Parliament. Minister of Transport Chris Bishop stated the legislation marks a 'major step forward in tackling congestion and improving productivity'. The law enables local authorities to partner with the NZ Transport Agency to implement targeted road pricing schemes. The Government has signalled its intention to partner with Auckland Council first, citing the city's importance to the national economy.

conclusion: The day was defined by the fallout from a damning police conduct report, while sharp ideological clashes over unemployment and social policy underscored deep divisions between the Government and Opposition.
